concept.title: Example: Using chunk to combine groups of topics
concept.shortdesc: The chunk attribute can be used on grouping elements to combine multiple source documents into one result document.

fig.title: Root map with chunk specified on topicgroup and topichead
fig.p: Consider the following DITA map, where chunk is specified on both topicgroup and topichead elements:
fig.codeblock: <map> <title>Groups are combined</title> <topicgroup chunk="combine"> <topicref href="ingroup1.dita"/> <topicref href="ingroup2.dita"/> </topicgroup> <topichead chunk="combine"> <topicmeta> <navtitle>Heading for a branch</navtitle> </topicmeta> <topicref href="inhead1.dita"/> <topicref href="inhead2.dita"/> </topichead> </map>

conbody.p: The result of evaluating the chunk attribute on the topicgroup element is equivalent to a single DITA document that contains the content of both ingroup1.dita and ingroup2.dita.

The chunk attribute on topichead also results in a single result document. In many applications, a topichead is equivalent to a single title-only topic. In that case, the chunked result is equivalent to a root topic with the title "Heading for a branch", containing as child topics the content of both inhead1.dita and inhead2.dita. If topichead is ignorable in the current processing context, the chunked result would be equivalent to processing topicgroup (a single DITA document with the content of both inhead1.dita and inhead2.dita).

fig.title: Equivalent content of source documents after evaluation
fig.p: The result of evaluating the chunk attribute is equivalent to the following map and topic documents:

<!-- chunkgroup-2.dita --> <dita> <topic id="head"> <title>Heading for a branch</title> <!-- content of inhead1.dita --> <!-- content of inhead2.dita --> </topic> </dita>
